description: Token-specific terminology for design token naming and structure

values.label: Component
values.description: In token naming, refers to the UI component the token is designed for

definition.description: A segment in a design token name that specifies which UI component or element the token value is intended for
essentialCharacteristics: Appears in token names like 'button-background-color' or 'component-edge-to-text'
Helps scope tokens to specific UI elements
May be generic ('component') or specific ('button', 'checkbox')
Improves token discoverability and organization

terminology.namingRationale: Standard term in design token methodology for component-specific tokens

values.label: Object
values.description: In token naming, refers to the specific part or element being styled

definition.description: A segment in a design token name that specifies what part of a component is being styled (text, icon, border, etc.)
essentialCharacteristics: Appears in token names like 'component-edge-to-text' or 'button-background'
Identifies the specific element receiving the design value
Common objects include: text, icon, visual, control, border, background
Helps create semantic, meaningful token names

terminology.namingRationale: Describes what is being styled or measured in a design token

values.label: Scale
values.description: In token naming, refers to the size or intensity level

definition.description: A segment in a design token name that indicates size, spacing, or intensity using numeric values (50, 75, 100, etc.) or t-shirt sizes (s, m, l, xl)
essentialCharacteristics: Provides graduated steps for spacing, sizing, and other properties
Common numeric scales: 50, 75, 100, 200, 300, 400, 500
T-shirt sizes also used: xs, s, m, l, xl, xxl, xxxl
Enables consistent scaling across the design system

terminology.namingRationale: Indicates relative size or intensity in a graduated system

values.label: Property
values.description: In token naming, refers to the CSS/style property being defined

definition.description: A segment in a design token name that specifies what CSS or style property the token value applies to (color, size, spacing, etc.)
essentialCharacteristics: Appears at the end of token names like 'button-background-color' or 'component-height'
Maps to CSS properties or style attributes
Common properties: color, size, width, height, spacing, border-width
Determines the type of value (color value, dimension, number, etc.)

terminology.namingRationale: Directly corresponds to CSS/style properties for clarity

values.label: Edge
values.description: In token naming, refers to the outer boundary of a component

definition.description: The outermost boundary of a component, used as a reference point for measuring spacing and layout
essentialCharacteristics: Used in spacing tokens like 'component-edge-to-text'
Refers to the component's bounding box
Different from 'visual' which may be inset from the edge
Critical for consistent component spacing

terminology.namingRationale: Objective spatial term that clearly indicates the component boundary

values.label: Visual
values.description: In token naming, refers to the visible graphic element of a component

definition.description: The visible graphic element within a component, which may be inset from the component's edge
essentialCharacteristics: Used in spacing tokens like 'component-edge-to-visual'
Represents the visible content area
May have padding or spacing between edge and visual
Distinguishes between bounding box and visible content

terminology.namingRationale: Objective term describing the visible content area

values.label: Structure
values.description: A reusable visual pattern or object category with shared styling that occurs across multiple component types

definition.description: An individual object or object category with shared styling that represents visual patterns occurring across many component varieties, distinct from components which represent specific UI elements
essentialCharacteristics: Represents visual patterns that occur across multiple components
Distinct from components—describes structural patterns, not specific UI elements
Maintains shared, consistent styling
Can be combined and composed to create components

terminology.namingRationale: Describes reusable visual patterns that form the building blocks of components

values.label: Base
values.description: Basic UI elements and visual structures combined to create proportionally sized content or components

definition.description: The foundational UI elements and visual structures that are combined and arranged to create proportionally relative sized content or components
essentialCharacteristics: Foundation for basic components like Button and Textfield
Used for inner structures of complex components such as List Item and Tree View Item
Represents common pairing and compositional choices for recurring basic UI elements
Creates proportionally relative sized content

terminology.namingRationale: Indicates the foundational nature of these structural elements

values.label: List
values.description: A vertically or horizontally oriented collection of items with varying complexity

definition.description: A collection of items arranged vertically or horizontally, where items can range from simple to complex and are composed of one or more base structures
essentialCharacteristics: Contains items ranging from simple (Radio) to complex (List view, Tabs, Menu)
Items composed of one or more base structures in horizontal arrangement
Items arranged vertically or horizontally into the list
Supports varying degrees of item complexity

terminology.namingRationale: Standard term for collections of items in UI design

values.label: Table
values.description: A grid structure arranging columns and rows of content

definition.description: A grid-based structure that arranges content into intersecting columns and rows
essentialCharacteristics: Arranges content in columns and rows
Provides grid-based layout structure
Used for tabular data presentation

terminology.namingRationale: Standard term for grid-based data structures in UI design

values.label: Container
values.description: A visible or invisible structure that houses custom content and components with consistent styling

definition.description: A structure that houses custom content and components with consistent styling, which may be visible or invisible depending on use
essentialCharacteristics: Can be visible or invisible
Houses custom content and components with consistent styling
Used in components like Popovers, Cards, and Select Boxes
Can provide spacing without visible styling (e.g., padding around side navigation)

terminology.namingRationale: Describes the containing nature of this structural element

values.label: Group
values.description: A collection of similar or related UI elements, inputs, or actions grouped together

definition.description: A collection of similar or closely related UI elements, inputs, or actions that are grouped together to form a cohesive functional unit
essentialCharacteristics: Groups similar or related elements together for cohesive interaction
Used in components like Button Group, Action Group, and Checkbox Group
Creates visual and functional unity among related items
Provides consistent spacing and alignment between grouped elements

terminology.namingRationale: Describes the grouping nature of this structural pattern

values.label: Drop Target
values.description: Visual indication of a UI region that can accept drop operations

definition.description: A consistently styled visual indication of a region within the UI that can accept drop operations during drag-and-drop interactions
essentialCharacteristics: Indicates regions that accept drop operations
Styled consistently across the design system
Provides visual feedback during drag-and-drop interactions

terminology.namingRationale: Describes the functional purpose of this visual indicator

values.label: Focus Ring
values.description: Visual indication of interactive keyboard focus on any UI element

definition.description: A consistently styled visual indicator that shows keyboard focus on any interactive UI element
essentialCharacteristics: Indicates keyboard focus on interactive elements
Styled consistently across all UI elements
Critical for keyboard accessibility

terminology.namingRationale: Standard accessibility term for keyboard focus indication

values.label: Accessory
values.description: Component-like structures used within basic components as secondary content or actions

definition.description: Smaller component-like structures used within basic components as secondary content or actions, sized to fit within base structure boundaries while conforming to t-shirt sizing rules
essentialCharacteristics: Intentionally smaller to fit within base structure boundaries
Conforms to t-shirt sizing rules for icon or text sizes
Used for interior sub-components or decorators of basic components
Examples include in-field buttons and Action button corner triangles
Distinct from structures like drill-in buttons which use base structures

terminology.namingRationale: Describes the supplementary nature of these interior elements

values.label: Banner
values.description: Horizontally-oriented, contained structure for drawing attention to non-permanent information or actions

definition.description: A horizontally-oriented, contained structure that may float or be fixed, designed to draw user attention to non-permanent information or actions
essentialCharacteristics: Horizontally oriented
May float or be fixed in position
Draws user attention to transient content
Contains non-permanent information or actions

terminology.namingRationale: Standard UI term for attention-drawing horizontal elements

values.label: Text
values.description: Text content within a component or structure

definition.description: The textual content element within a component or structure
essentialCharacteristics: Represents textual content
Used within other structures and components

terminology.namingRationale: Fundamental term for textual content in UI

values.label: Substructure
values.description: A structural element that exists within or as part of a larger structure

definition.description: A structural element that exists within or as part of a parent structure, representing smaller building blocks that compose structures
essentialCharacteristics: Exists within or as part of a larger structure
Represents smaller building blocks
Can be used across different structure types

terminology.namingRationale: Indicates the hierarchical relationship to parent structures

values.label: Item
values.description: An individual element of a collection, regardless of collection type

definition.description: An individual element within a collection, applicable regardless of the collection type it belongs to
essentialCharacteristics: Individual element within a collection
Collection-agnostic—applies to any collection type
Building block for list, table, and other collection structures

terminology.namingRationale: Generic term for collection elements that applies across structure types

values.label: Padding
values.description: The internal spacing from the edges of a component's boundary to its contents

definition.description: A stylistic attribute that defines the internal spacing from the edges of a component's boundary to its contents
essentialCharacteristics: Defines space between component boundary edges and inner contents
Applied internally within a component
Platform-agnostic term with high comprehension across engineers and designers

terminology.namingRationale: Standard CSS and design term for internal spacing from boundaries

values.label: Gap
values.description: The internal spacing between child elements in a component, layout, or pattern

definition.description: A stylistic attribute that defines the internal spacing between child elements in a component, layout, or pattern
essentialCharacteristics: Defines spacing between child elements, not from boundaries
Used in components, layouts, and patterns
Aligns with CSS gap property and Figma auto-layout gap
Preferred over 'spacing' for specificity and modern standards alignment

terminology.namingRationale: Aligns with CSS gap property and Figma terminology, preferred over 'spacing' for specificity

values.label: Orientation
values.description: The direction or order of structures and elements within a component or pattern

definition.description: A category describing the direction or order of structures and elements within a component or pattern
essentialCharacteristics: Defines direction or order of elements
Options include horizontal (left to right, right to left) and vertical (top to bottom, bottom to top)
Applies to structures and elements within components or patterns

terminology.namingRationale: Standard term for describing directional arrangement of elements

values.label: Shape
values.description: Describes the geometric characteristics of a component's style attributes

definition.description: A category describing the geometric characteristics of a component's style attributes
essentialCharacteristics: Describes geometric characteristics of styling
Applies to component style attributes
Includes variations like uniform dimensions

terminology.namingRationale: Describes the geometric form characteristics of component styling

values.label: Uniform
values.description: Signifies that the shape of a component's style attributes is equal in all directions

definition.description: A shape characteristic signifying that a component's style attributes are equal in all directions
essentialCharacteristics: Equal values across dimensions (e.g., vertical and horizontal)
Results in symmetrical shapes (e.g., square padding when showing an icon only)
Applies to attributes like padding where dimensional equality matters

terminology.namingRationale: Describes dimensional equality in component styling

values.label: Position
values.description: The placement of an element relative to its container or viewport

definition.description: A category describing the placement of an element relative to its container or viewport
essentialCharacteristics: Defines element placement
Relative to container or viewport
Includes variations like affixed positioning

terminology.namingRationale: Standard term for describing element placement in layouts

values.label: Affixed
values.description: The position of an element fixed relative to its container or the viewport

definition.description: A position characteristic where an element is fixed relative to its container or the viewport
essentialCharacteristics: Element position is fixed relative to container or viewport
Maintains position regardless of content scrolling
Used for persistent UI elements like headers or toolbars

terminology.namingRationale: Describes fixed positioning behavior relative to a reference point

values.label: Size
values.description: Relative t-shirt-size terms used to create relationships and patterns across tokens

definition.description: A category of relative t-shirt-size terms used to create relationships and patterns of usage across multiple tokens and token types
essentialCharacteristics: Uses t-shirt size terminology (extra-small, small, medium, large, extra-large)
Creates relationships and patterns across multiple tokens and token types
Can construct standard components or be used irregularly for novel or custom components

terminology.namingRationale: T-shirt sizing is an industry-standard approach for relative sizing in design systems
